titleStmt.title: Persian MS 910
titleStmt.funder: Iran Heritage Foundation and The John Rylands Research Institute

msContents.summary: A fine copy containing the Baysunghur introduction and one hundred illustrations. Completed by two groups of earlier 16th century and later early 17th century Safavid painters, many scenes bears signs of overpainting, which together with many historical repairs, and the binding, all appear probably executed in India.

msItem.title: Shāhnāmah
شاهنامه
msItem.incipit: برگ ۶ پ (folio 6b): اففتاح سخن آن به که کنند اهل کمال به ثنای ملک الملک خدای منعال مالک الملکی که در تدبیر ملک و ملکوت و ترتیب عوالم لاهوت و ناسوت بوزیر و مشیر و طیر و نصیر محتاج و مفقر نگشت پادشاهی و سلطنت او را سلم ست که ملک سرمد او از سقیص زوال و نکبت تحویل و اشقال مصون و مامونست و حشمت و عظمش از ندلیتانقضا و نهایت انقطاع و اشها معرا و مبرا ...
برگ ۱۶پ (folio 16b): بنام خداوند جان و فرد * کزین بر تر اندیشه بر نگذرد
msItem.explicit: برگ ۵۶۲ر (folio 562a): بفرمان او باد یکسر ز می * مشیرد ازو شادی و خرمی | ز هجرت شده هیچ هشتاد با * بنام جهان داور کرد کار.
msItem.colophon: برگ ۵۶۲ر (folio 562a): تم الکتاب بعون الملک الوهاب فی سادس شهر جمادی الاول سنة اربع و تسع(؟)

Completed ...on 6 Jumādà I in the year 4 and 9 but the exact date appears altered and unclear. Kerney disregarded the date and attributed the volume to circa 978 AH (1570 CE); however, Robinson read the date as possibly Jumādà I 924 AH (25 May 1518 CE), while Charles Melville suggests Jumādà I 904 AH (29 Dec. 1498 CE) also could prove plausible, an this attribution that the earlier depictive schemes seem to support.

supportDesc.support: Textblock of domestic, straight-grained, ivoury-coloured paper probably handmade in the Greater Iran with 8 laid lines per cm and no discernible chain lines.
supportDesc.foliation: Modern Arabic numerals pencilled on the upper-left corners of the a sides, inclusive of all but the very first and final endleaves.
supportDesc.collation: Undetermined. Catchwords throughout most of the lower-left corners of the b sides.
supportDesc.condition: In fair condition, with moderate water and insect damage and historical repairs throughout.

layoutDesc.layout: Written in 1, 2, but primarily in 4 columns with 25 lines per page. Ruled with a misṭārah hand guide.

handDesc.handNote: Written in clear black nasta‘līq with subheaders in red.

decoDesc.decoNote: Headpiece: Folio 6b bears a scalloped domed headpiece with gilt palmette foliate scrollwork on an ultramarine ground above a horiztonal cartouche with the phrase Dībāchah-'i Kitāb (Introduction of the Book).
Carpet Pages: Folios 16a–b, which commence the work proper.
Ruling: 5a onwards ruled in gold outlined with single internal and double external black lines.

Illustrations: B. W. Robinson identifies five different artists, an 'Earlier Group' Pwith ainters A, B, and C and a 'Later Group' comprised of Painters D and E. To the first group, he assigns 14 scenes to Painter A (with another 7 doubtful), whom he describes as 'of mediocre attainments, probably brought up in the commercial Turkman style'; however he attributes 26 illustrations (2 doubtful), to Painter B, and to the nascent Safavid court at Tabriz under Shah Ismā'īl I. Robinson attributes 19 illustrations (1 or 2 doubtful) to Painter C whom he regards as an artist 'of great distinction and fine technique' who worked during the reign of Shāh Ṭahmāsp. group, Robinson attributes the later group to early 17th-century Isfahan, then a newly established capital under Shāh ‘Abbās I, and identifies Painter D as a E's pupil and describes him as 'competent... working at high speed' while E displays a 'both and effective' mastery of the 'new style'.

Published: Robinson, Persian Paintings in the John Rylands Library, p. 263. The first of the second set of paintings in this ms., dating from c. 1570-80, or a decade later, in anticipation of the Isfahan style, and also the work of three separate artists. The paintings here too have suffered some retouching in India.

physDesc.additions:
Inscriptions:
The right flyleaf a side (f. ia): bears an English description of the work and the spurious claim that it was presented to the Sultan of Ghazna.
Bookplates: The final right flyleaf b side (f. iiib): Bibliotheca Lindesiana with pencilled shelfmark F/3.

binding.p: Probably rebound in the Indian subcontinent in the 18th century.
Covered in full, claret-coloured goatskin leather over pasteboards.
binding.decoNote: white medallions, pendants, corners and border panels inlaid and embossed. Doublures with medallions and pendants painted in silver.

history.origin: Probably originally completed in Tabriz; ambiguously dated ...on 6 Jumādà I in the year 4 and 9... but the exact date appears altered and unclear. Michael Kerney disregarded the date and attributed the volume to circa 978 AH (1570 CE); however, Robinson read the date as possibly Jumādà I 924 AH (25 May 1518 CE), while Charles Melville suggests it may read Jumādà I 904 AH (29 Dec. 1498 CE) also could prove plausible, an this attribution that the earlier depictive schemes seem to support.

provenance.p:
Probably the same volume described by British Museum curator Charles Rieu (1820–1902) in a letter dated 27 June 1885 to Alexander Lindsay, 25th Earl of Crawford (1812–1880): I have on hand a fair MS. of the Shahnameh sent to me from Madras. It is from the library of the Navabs of the Carnatic. It is complete, fairly written, and contains about hundred miniatures in Persian style and in good preservation. The date has been obliterated, but it is in all probability A.H. 994 A.D. 1586 a good period for Persian art. We are as your Lordship knows well supplied with Shahnameh so that I could not think of purchasing it for the Museum. The owner, Zahoor Ouddeen Khan, a relative of the late Navvab sends word through Col. H. McLeod, Royal Artillery, that he will take £50 for it…’
Then in a subsequent letter dated 1 July 1885, Rieu thanks Lindsay for sending a cheque for £50, proving the latter's acceptance of the volume, and adds I am glad to see that you found the Shahnameh sufficiently interesting to be worthy of a place in your collection by the side of the six copies it already contains. That six complete compies precede this volume's class mark would also comport with this information.
Subsequently purchased by Enriqueta Rylands (1843–1908) in 1901 from James Ludovic Lindsay, 26th Earl of Crawford (1847–1913).

acquisition.p: Bequeathed by Enriqueta Rylands (1843–1908) in 1908 to the John Rylands Library.

source.p: Bibliographical description based upon B. W. Robinson, Persian Paintings in the John Rylands Library: A Descriptive Catalogue and an index by Reza Navabpour circa 1993, derived from a manuscript catalogue by Michael Kerney, circa 1890s, concisely published as Bibliotheca Lindesiana, Hand-list of Oriental Manuscripts: Arabic, Persian, Turkish, 1898.
Manuscript description by Jake Benson in 2022 with reference to the volume in hand, with illustration descriptions supplied by the Cambridge Shahnama Project.

availability.p: The manuscript is available for consultation by any accredited reader, see Becoming a Reader for details. Please contact uml.special-collections@manchester.ac.uk for further information on the availability of this manuscript.

custodialHist.custEvent: Exhibited in Persian Miniature Painting from collections in the British Isles at the Victoria and Albert Museum, Kensington, London, in 1967.

custEvent.p: Exhibited in Gilded Word and Radiant Image, in 9 Sept. to 21 Dec. 1992, sponsored by Altajir Trust.
Exhibited in Heroes and Kings: The Shahnama of Ferdowsi 18 Feb. to 27 Jun. 2010, also sponsored by the Altajir Trust together with the Iran Society

custodialHist.custEvent: Exhibited in The Shahnameh: A Persian Cultural Emblem and a Timeless Masterpiece at the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge in 2010.

listBibl.bibl: J. Norgren & E. Davis, Preliminary index of Shah-nameh illustrations, Ann Arbor, Center for Near Eastern and North African Studies, University of Michigan, 1969.
C. Melville, 'Serial killers: The mise-en-page of Firdausi's 'Davazdah rukh'. Persica 23, (2009-2010) 73–107.
B. W. Robinson, Persian Paintings in the John Rylands Library: A Descriptive Catalogue (London: Sotheby Parke Bernet, 1980), pp. 158–163.

change.persName: Completed preliminary description of ms, added image descriptions from Cambridge Shahnama Project and Robinson catalogue.
